title: Schneier on Security
summary:
LinkedIn Job ScamsInteresting article on the variety of LinkedIn job scams around the world:In India, tech jobs are used as bait because the industry employs millions of people and offers high-paying roles.
In Kenya, the recruitment industry is largely unorganized, so scamsters leverage fake personal referrals.
In Mexico, bad actors capitalize on the informal nature of the job economy by advertising fake formal roles that carry a promise of security.
These are scams involving fraudulent employers convincing prospective employees to send them money for various fees.
There is an entirely different set of scams involving fraudulent employees getting hired for remote jobs.

title: Two cybersecurity employees plead guilty to carrying out ransomware attacks
summary:
Is a news writer who covers the streaming wars, consumer tech, crypto, social media, and much more.
Posts from this author will be added to your daily email digest and your homepage feed.
Two former employees at cybersecurity firms — one of whom was a ransomware negotiator — have pleaded guilty to carrying out a series of ransomware attacks in 2023.
Goldberg, Martin, and an unnamed co-conspirator were indicted for the attacks in October, which involved using ALPHV / BlackCat ransomware to encrypt and steal data from their victims.
“These defendants used their sophisticated cybersecurity training and experience to commit ransomware attacks — the very type of crime that they should have been working to stop,” Assistant Attorney General A. Tysen Duva of the DOJ’s Criminal Division says in a statement.

title: The Worst Hacks of 2025
summary:
Through it all, the steady drumbeat kept pounding of data breaches, leaks, ransomware attacks, digital extortion cases, and state-sponsored attacks that have unfortunately become a backdrop of daily life.
Clop’s Oracle E-Business Hacking SpreeThe ransomware group Clop is known for carrying out mass exploitation of vulnerabilities for data breaches and extortion attacks.
This year, the group did it again, exploiting a vulnerability in Oracle’s E-Business internal management platform to steal data from numerous companies and organizations.
The data included email addresses, phone numbers, physical addresses, event attendance records, information about donations to the university and other fundraising details.
Princeton University was hit with a similar attack that same month, although the scope of affected data seems more limited.

title: A 2025 recap for Tech & AI
summary:
Tech leaders and investors had begun asking harder questions: beyond impressive demos, could these models drive real products and revenue?
The hunger for AI computers in 2025 was insatiable, and chipmakers raced to deliver.
Workplace AI adoption soared this year; tools like Microsoft 365 Copilot and a host of AI assistants became common on office desktops.
The editor’s verdict: Lovable wins 2025Lovable (Stockholm, Sweden) came as one of the most remarkable AI software stories of the year, for me.
If 2024 was the year the world grasped the power of generative AI, 2025 was the year it began deciding how that power should be used.

title: 4 key ways AI changed the Big Four in 2025
summary:
Here are my four key takeaways about how the Big Four approached AI in 2025.
The year of the AI agentThe Big Four have invested heavily in automation and AI for years, but 2025 was the year those tools went mainstream.
KPMG followed in June with KPMG Workbench, an agentic AI platform developed with Microsoft that connects 50 AI agents and chatbots, with nearly 1,000 more in development.
In 2025, organizations fit AI around their existing workflows, Matt Wood, PwC's global and US Chief Technology and Innovation Officer, told Business Insider.
They'll be managing teams of AI agents and play a greater role in strategy decisions, he said.

title: 3 people who pivoted into AI share how they used their college experience to break into the field
summary:
For one AI startup engineer, returning to school provided an opportunity to explore what an AI career would be like before committing to it.
Below are three people who pivoted into AI roles and shared with Business Insider how they leveraged their college experience to break into the field.
Without going back for my master's, I wouldn't have had this opportunity, and I love working in AI.
I leaned on college mentors and peers to build my AI career at GoogleDeep Shah has been an engineer at Google since 2018.
I'm now part of the Foundation Model main framework team for a major Big Tech company in the US.

title: Israeli innovation is under threat as tech employees seek relocation abroad: report
summary:
Some of the world's largest tech companies have a presence in Israel, including Apple, Meta, Nvidia, Amazon, Microsoft, IBM, and Google.
Israel's tech sector is a key driver of its economy.
The Israel Innovation Authority, a government body, said the tech industry contributed one-fifth of the country's GDP in 2023.
The IATI report said that there are around 430 multinational companies in Israel, with around 90,000 high-tech employees working for them.
Dror Bin, the CEO of the Israel Innovation Authority, previously said that the Israeli economy's dependence on the high-tech sector had "significantly grown in the past decade."

title: Cato Networks CEO says we are in an AI bubble
summary:
The CEO of cybersecurity company Cato Networks may have just validated the fears of many: that the dot-com era could be repeating itself.
"We are in a bubble," Shlomo Kramer, who runs the company aimed at securing organizations' digital and AI transformation, told Business Insider.
He said AI may be able to increase effectiveness and productivity to them in specific areas or situations, but it can't replace engineers.
Kramer is the latest CEO to weigh in on the debate about an AI bubble.
The CEO of Nvidia, the chipmaker that's fueling the AI revolution, has denied the existence of an AI bubble, while Mark Zuckerberg has said the bigger risk is not spending enough.

title: I've Spent 18 Years Covering Autos at CES. Flying, Thinking, Autonomous Cars Are Closer Than Ever
summary:
At my first CES, car tech was mostly aftermarket car audio equipment and portable GPS devices.
Rise of the 'flying cars'At this point, it's basically a given that there will be at least one "flying car" showcased at CES 2026.
In 2024, the big news was Hyundai's air mobility wing, Supernal, debuting its flight-ready electric air taxi.
An AI friend in your dashboardAbout the only CES automotive prediction more certain than cars that fly are cars that think.
I'm talking about autonomous delivery robots, electric go-karts, self-balancing motorcycles and crazy alternative mobility concepts.

title: 3 New Tricks to Try With Google Gemini Live After Its Latest Major Upgrade
summary:
Gemini Live is the more conversational, natural language way of interacting with the Google Gemini AI bot using your voice.
To access Gemini Live, launch the Gemini app, then tap the Live button in the lower right hand corner (it looks vaguely like a sound wave) and start talking.
The Gemini Live interface.
You can even get Gemini Live to teach you a language.
If you need Gemini Live to slow down, speed up, or repeat something, then just say so.

title: 2025 was the year of VC FOMO. A 'reckoning' might be coming in 2026.
summary:
Photo: Marijan Murat/dpa (Photo by Marijan Murat/picture alliance via Getty Images)A girl reaches up to burst a large bubble on the Palace Plaza in Stuttgart, Germany, 19 October 2017.
Photo: Marijan Murat/dpa (Photo by Marijan Murat/picture alliance via Getty Images) Marijan Murat/picture alliance via Getty ImagesA girl reaches up to burst a large bubble on the Palace Plaza in Stuttgart, Germany, 19 October 2017.
"2026 will be a year of reckoning," said Deedy Das, a partner at Menlo Ventures focused on AI and machine learning.
VCs have been writing big checks into AI startups at the same time as it becomes harder for them to replenish their coffers.
"And on top of that, I think we are underestimating the potential total addressable market for a lot of these AI companies."

title: Report: Apple's AI Strategy Could Finally Pay Off in 2026
summary:
Apple's restrained artificial intelligence strategy may pay off in 2026 amid the arrival of a revamped Siri and concerns around the AI market "bubble" bursting, The Information argues.
The report argues that market sentiment toward AI spending is beginning to show signs of skepticism, with questions emerging over whether such large investments can be justified by near-term revenue.
Apple's biggest AI-related move in 2026 will be the long-anticipated overhaul of ‌Siri‌, which is expected to arrive in the spring.
In addition, Apple's AI chief John Giannandrea announced his retirement earlier in December, with parts of his organization redistributed into product-focused teams amid internal concerns about a lack of clear product direction.
2026 may be an inflection point in which Apple's cautious strategy could appear prescient if enthusiasm for large-scale AI spending continues to cool and the company finally delivers a more capable version of ‌Siri‌.

title: China is considering a raft of new controls for training AI on chat log data. Here's what it means.
summary:
China is proposing new rules that require user consent before AI companies can use chat logs to train their models.
China is proposing new rules that require user consent before AI companies can use chat logs to train their models.
d3sign/Getty ImagesChina is proposing new rules that require user consent before AI companies can use chat logs to train their models.
Tightening controls over chat logs signals that certain user conversations are too sensitive to be treated as free training data, he added.
AI chatlog safetyChina's new draft rules on chatlog data come as concerns grow over how AI companies handle deeply personal user conversations.

title: MongoDB, AppLovin, and SoundHound AI Stocks Trade Down, What You Need To Know
summary:
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were under pressure as the dominant artificial intelligence trade cooled off.
The stock market overreacts to news, and big price drops can present good opportunities to buy high-quality stocks.
Among others, the following stocks were impacted:Zooming In On AppLovin (APP)AppLovin’s shares are extremely volatile and have had 58 moves greater than 5% over the last year.
Technology stocks with a focus on artificial intelligence once again led the market higher, boosting the Nasdaq and S&P 500.
The rally reflected a renewed belief among investors in the transformative potential of AI technology to drive future growth and productivity.

title: 6 ways creative agencies can future-proof their teams for the AI era
summary:
Jules Love, founder of Spark AI, a consultancy that helps creative firms weave AI into their day-to-day work.
Jules Love, founder of Spark AI, a consultancy that helps creative firms weave AI into their day-to-day work.
Courtesy of Jules LoveJules Love, founder of Spark AI, a consultancy that helps creative firms weave AI into their day-to-day work.
Jules Love, founder of Spark AI, a consultancy that helps creative firms weave AI into their day-to-day work, says the real challenge isn't technical — it's psychological.
Drawing on his work with more than 60 agencies through Spark AI, he shares six ways leaders can future-proof their teams for the AI era.

title: 3 Semiconductor Stocks Well-Poised for a Comeback in 2026
summary:
Semiconductor stocks have experienced a significant rally in 2025 despite a highly volatile market environment due to tariffs, inflationary pressures, high interest rates and geopolitical issues.
According to the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics report, global semiconductor sales are expected to surge 26.3% year over year to $975.4 billion in 2026.
AI accelerators, high-bandwidth memory (HBM), advanced logic chips and supporting infrastructure are expected to be the primary growth engines.
Investors looking to benefit from this trend should consider investing in semiconductor stocks.
In our opinion, NVIDIA Corporation NVDA, Micron Technology, Inc. MU and Amphenol Corporation APH are some of the stocks that are positioned to benefit as semiconductor demand spikes in 2026.

title: What is Manus, the Chinese-founded AI startup Meta is buying for over $2 billion?
summary:
Manus grabbed headlines in March when it unveiled an AI agent designed to autonomously execute tasks like résumé screening and stock analysis.
Launched in March by the Chinese AI product studio Butterfly Effect, Manus has been pitched by its creators as the world's first "general" AI agent — a system designed to carry out tasks independently.
Buying Manus could give Meta an AI revenue boost and give it a distribution advantage, Business Insider's Hugh Langley wrote.
"There will be no continuing Chinese ownership interests in Manus AI following the transaction, and Manus AI will discontinue its services and operations in China," the spokesperson told Business Insider.
Manus employees who join Meta will not have access to customer data, and Meta will continue to geo-block access to its AI models, the spokesperson added.

title: Study reveals we were told a 50-year-long lie about common household appliance — here's why it was covered up
summary:
A shocking study from December 2022 revealed that gas stoves cause one in eight cases of childhood asthma, in addition to contributing to a wide range of other health issues.
More recent reporting from the accountability site DeSmog reveals that both the gas industry and the government knew about these risks as far back as 50 years ago.
However, as Grist reports, the gas industry managed to cover up these health hazards for decades.
The group showed evidence that gas appliances, such as gas stoves, were likely leaking poisonous carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide into homes.
According to Mayo Clinic, "childhood asthma is the leading cause of emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and missed school days."

title: 20 Years of Make: Triumph of the Makers
summary:
Twenty years ago, I wrote a column called “News from the Future” for the first issue of Make: magazine.
I based it on the notion from science-fiction writer William Gibson that “The future is here.
It’s just not evenly distributed yet.” Makers, hackers, hobbyists, and enthusiasts, I argued, are living in a future that we will all one day catch up to.
The list of projects from early issues of Make: did indeed bring momentous news from the future.
Everyone is going to learn to use AI, just as everyone learns to use a smartphone today.

title: US fusion strategy stuck in past as China moves ahead, CEO warns
summary:
"Fusion is at an inflection point," Commonwealth Fusion Systems (CFS) CEO Bob Mumgaard told FOX Business.
THIS DEAL IS ABOUT ENERGY OF THE FUTURE, EXPERT REVEALSMumgaard sees China as the U.S.’s main competitor as Beijing ramps up investment and coordination around fusion energy.
In July, People's Daily Online, the Chinese Communist Party’s (CCP) official newspaper, reported that Beijing had launched the China Fusion Energy Co. Ltd (CFEC), a subsidiary of the China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC).
We have a fusion program that looks like it did when it was in the 90s, and so we need to modernize that."
"In the early 2030s, all eyes will be on the Richmond region, and more specifically Chesterfield County, Virginia, as the birthplace of commercial fusion energy."

title: TSMC says started mass production of 'most advanced' 2nm chips
summary:
A worker walks past the 2-nanometer fabrication plant of TSMC at Nanzih Technology Industrial Park in Kaohsiung on December 23, 2025 (I-Hwa Cheng)Taiwanese tech titan TSMC has started mass producing its cutting-edge 2-nanometre semiconductor chips, the company said in a statement seen by AFP on Wednesday.
TSMC is the world's largest contract maker of chips, used in everything from smartphones to missiles, and counts Nvidia and Apple among its clients.
"TSMC's 2nm (N2) technology has started volume production in 4Q25 as planned," TSMC said in an undated statement on its website.
The chips will be the "most advanced technology in the semiconductor industry in terms of both density and energy efficiency", the company said.
But in an interview with AFP this month, Taiwanese Deputy Foreign Minister Francois Chih-chung Wu said the island planned to keep making the "most advanced" chips on home soil and remain "indispensable" to the global semiconductor industry.
